message: You know how you can write on walls with a laser?  This will be like a LED scroller, only smaller.  You could project it through your friends window across the street to tell him the party is on!
So he'd see a projection on the wall "hey come over, party is on"
I could even see this being used for long distance communication.  Say you are out at sea, you could project a message to another boat.
Where audible communication cannot reach...
And what about a morse-code-translating transceiver? I mean... Even Ham Radio users don't know morse. This would be a simple layer of encryption, decryption,

@psytek 8 Mirrors correspond to 8 vertical display positions.  I'm a little uncertain how the horizontal spread is accomplished.  I guess you hit the mirror at different points in its rotation, to achieve horizontal spread.  I suppose this means you must calculate the distance to target...

1 of the benefits of lasers is always being in focus - it would be a shame to lose that. How about laser-cutting some precise mirroring devices (mirrored plexiglas?), to fit calculations, rather than letting calculations determine form?
What about a small LCD screen, w/backing removed, and a laser through that? Would  polarized LCD glass be good or bad for focus?
There would need to be a curved screen or a lens, or the image would distort

Hmm.. Could it be collimated w/2 opposing lenses, surrounding LCD? Laser would have to be stronger, as beam would be wider. Green would be the best choice, for safety & visibility, but would draw more current & possibly overheat...

no need for mirrors or motors just an array of lasers 100 or so of them, shift registers, can use the same code we use at the lab.  Plexiglass will be good, we can cut a bunch of circles and glue in the lasers.  If its flexible enough we could bend the plexi a bit and make the scroller bigger or smaller too.

If this could be AC-powered & cooled, current kept consistent, shock-resistant, I think Green's the obvious choice. Red makes more sense in price. Other colors don't really present a viable alternative, except IR, for "invisible" writing.
+1 for green
Lasers are so damn delicate. Maybe a red prototype would be a good idea, price-wise.
